text: I sat down at the KDRV in Medford to discuss the recent passage of the Continuing Resolution, provided an update on Congressional priorities, the vital importance of Medicaid and shared insights from my recent Tele-Town Halls. https://t.co/xI7YibPp1p

It was an honor and privilege to welcome Korean and Vietnam Veterans to Washington, D.C. for the Honor Flight of Central Oregon! 

I had the opportunity to present these brave veterans with a United States flags flown over our nation’s Capitol, along with a Congressional Record, thanking and recognizing their invaluable service to our country.

This morning, I had the honor of welcoming Korean, Vietnam and Global War on Terrorism (GWOT) Veterans to D.C., courtesy of the Honor Flight of Southern Oregon. 

I presented these brave Veterans with a flag flown over our nation’s Capitol, accompanied by a certificate so indicating, and with a copy of the Congressional Record thanking and recognizing them for their service to our country. 

These patriots defended the U.S. and fought for our freedom with honor and courage. They deserve our support and gratitude for their service to our nation.

Today, I had the opportunity to meet with Jerry Scott CEO of Elmer’s Restaurant Inc., here with the International Franchise Association. We discussed the exciting news of a new Elmer’s Diner opening in Bend, Oregon, and the importance of the American Franchise Act. This piece of legislation will help provide stability for the franchise model by aligning federal law with longstanding precedent and NLRB policy, while making sure small business owners can continue to thrive. 

Thank you for visiting my Washington, D.C. office!

REMINDER: Do not forget to join me TONIGHT Wednesday, September 17th at 5:30pm PT for my Telephone Town Hall! 

You can participate in tonight’s telephone town hall by clicking the link below to listen ⬇️

https://t.co/Cxo5P7fqCM https://t.co/woCQDDdqLG

As a Member of Congress, I have the honor of nominating eligible candidates from Oregon’s Second Congressional District for appointment to the United States Service Academies. Students interested in a congressional nomination for Fall 2025 admission should visit https://t.co/dNd6hqeyEz for more details about the process and to request a nomination packet.

Completed nomination packets must be received by my Southern Oregon District Office no later than Friday, October 31, 2025.

Great news for Union County! I was glad to support the Grande Ronde Hospital’s grant (see attached letter). Today, I am pleased to share that Grande Ronde Hospital has received the $2.2 million dollars from the EDA to renovate its Acute and Behavioral Health Care Workforce Development Center in La Grande, Oregon. This project will expand and modernize a medical office building. Once completed, it is expected to create 156 new jobs while also saving 121 existing jobs. 

Thank you to the EDA for their continued support of rural communities!

Don’t forget to join me for my Tele-Town Hall for tomorrow Wednesday, September 17th at 5:30PM PT for Umatilla, Union, Baker, Gilliam, Malheur, Grant, Harney, Lake, Wallowa, Morrow, and Wheeler Counties! I look forward to hearing from you and discuss issues that matter most to you and your family! 

To participate, visit my website ⬇️

https://t.co/sEd1ET8A6T

This week, I met with leaders from Oregon’s Credit Unions to discuss important legislative priorities and what we can do to improve the business environment in Oregon. We also spoke at length about the growing threat of fraud, including how bad actors are using AI and other new methods to defraud our citizens.

ICYMI:  In the @HouseCommerce Subcommittee on Energy, I discussed with the Chairman of the National Association of Home Builders on the cost of Oregon’s building standards which often adds 10–20% to the price of a home. While Mr. Hughes did say that these standards are “essential” he also admitted that they should ultimately be up to the homeowner. We do need more housing, and the real problem lies in inconsistent code enforcement by inspectors and whether on so-called “green” codes or not. He agreed. 

Those in Oregon deserve affordable homes, not endless red tape and arbitrary enforcement.

Thank you to the Eastern Oregon County Commissioners, Lisa Collier, Jake Seavert, Derrick DeGroot, Rob Frank and Paul Anderes for visiting me in Washington, D.C.! In our discussion I spoke about my legislation to delist gray wolves in Oregon and Washington, the urgent need to reauthorize Secure Rural Schools (SRS), and how counties will continue to be supported through the Working Family Tax Cuts.

ICYMI: In the Federal Lands Subcommittee on @NatResources, I questioned Chief Tom Schultz of the U.S. Forest Service regarding the disastrous wildfires devastating not only our nation but also communities across Oregon. In my questions to Chief Schultz, I pressed on key issues such as fire insurance, misconceptions about the availability of wildland firefighters and contractors, and the need to strengthen wildland-urban interface zones to protect our communities. I look forward to continuing these conversations with Chief Schultz as we work towards a safer, more resilient federal forests.
Charlie was a passionate voice and leader for the conservative movement. My prayers are with Charlie and his family.

Thank you to everyone who joined my Telephone Town Hall earlier this week! We had over 8,610 constituents join our call. It was great to take your questions and hear directly from you about issues that matter most to Oregon.

Don’t forget to join my next Telephone Town Hall on Wednesday, September 17th, at 5:30 PM PT for Umatilla, Union, Baker, Gilliam, Malheur, Grant, Harney, Lake, Wallowa, Morrow, and Wheeler Counties! 

Tune in at https://t.co/jPCnZAPXUP

Today I spoke at the National Association of Counties about the importance of PILT and Secure Rural Schools (SRS) for our rural communities. In my speech, I gave the an update on my efforts in the House to reauthorize SRS and make sure those funds reach the counties that depend on them most.  I also discussed the importance of counties recognizing the wins delivered through the Working Family Tax Cuts. 

It was also great to see Senator @RonWyden and hear his update on his efforts to reauthorize SRS in the Senate.

Don’t forget to join me for my Tele-Town Hall tonight Monday, September 8th at 5:30 PM PT for Klamath, Deschutes, Crook, Jefferson, Wasco, and Sherman Counties! I look forward to hearing from you and discussing the issues that matter most to you and your family.

To participate, visit my website ⬇️

https://t.co/jPCnZAPq5h

In Morrow County, I had the opportunity to meet with wheat growers, farmers, and ranchers who work every day to provide the high-quality food on which we all depend. Agriculture is the backbone of our communities and essential to Oregon’s economy. During our meeting, we discussed the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) and how it delivers for our producers.

We also spoke about working closely with the Administration’s agencies to address the ongoing challenges of wolf management. Thank you to everyone who joined me, including Senator Todd Nash and Representative Bobby Levy!

In Heppner, I visited with Ann Murray at Murray’s Drug. We discussed the many challenges independent pharmacies face with pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) and how PBM practices make it harder for local pharmacies to serve their communities. Thank you Ann for sharing your thoughts and all your work to ensuring our communities have access to quality care.

Today I met with Teresa Hunt and her team at the Asher Clinic in Fossil. I learned more about the important work being done at the facilities in Mitchell and Spray. Together, these clinics do an excellent job serving all of Wheeler County. We had a great discussion about the actual facts regarding the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) and how these facilities will not be impacted. Thank you to all the staff for all the great work they provide!

Today, I met with Fossil Mayor Carol MacInnes, Wheeler County Sheriff Jeremiah Holmes, Fossil Public Works Director Bill Potter, and City Recorder Lea Moyer. I appreciated the opportunity to hear directly from these local leaders about the challenges facing Fossil, which include the water system and the continued importance of increasing timber management to reduce the threat of wildfire near Wheeler County communities.

This morning, I met with Veterans in John Day. As always, I appreciate the time spent with each of them. These patriots defended our country and protected our freedom with honor and courage. They certainly deserve our support and gratitude for their service to our nation. 

During my time in Congress, I have supported our veterans by voting for 170 veteran related bills. In addition, my office has helped approximately 1,352 veterans across the Second Congressional District of Oregon with issues ranging from VA benefits to healthcare access. 

To all veterans: if you need assistance with the VA or any other federal services, please contact my Medford office at (541) 776-4646. My staff and I are here to help!

It was great to join Logan Bagett on Coffee Time at KJDY Radio. We discussed everything from the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) to my work with the Administration to make sure rural Oregon’s priorities are heard in Washington, D.C. https://t.co/5BPRMRqN50

Had a great conversation with Mt. Vernon Mayor Kenny Delano today! We discussed the reconciliation package and its impact on our small communities, the importance of simplifying zoning modifications so more housing can be built, and other key funding needs. Thank you for meeting with me!

Last week, the Oregon Nurse’s Association held a meeting in Madras to discuss the impact of the “One Big Beautiful Bill” (OBBB) on the Madras hospital. This meeting was attended by one of my Oregon congressional Democratic colleagues. At the meeting it was apparently said that the OBBB would cause the closure of the Madras Hospital. This statement has caused distress. To get the facts, I met today and yesterday with the hospital’s leadership. Also in attendance was Jefferson County Commissioner Kelly Semmilink. They made it absolutely clear that St. Charles Madras is NOT closing, is in no danger whatsoever of closing, and that they strongly believe, for excellent reasons, that the St. Charles’ system will manage just fine through the changes imposed by the OBBB.
 
They assured me that St. Charles has been and remains committed to continue providing access to quality care across Central Oregon. 
 
I look forward to continuing to work closely with the St. Charles leadership team to ensure St. Charles Madras remains strong and continues serving the Central Oregon community for years to come.

Today, I visited the interagency Redmond Air Base which is home to the Redmond Smokejumpers, the Air Tanker base and the dispatch center. Thank you to all our firefighters for the great work they have done this year on initial attack on fires across Oregon. They have done an excellent job this year to ensure our entire summer hasn’t been filled with smoke. I appreciate their commitment as they put themselves on the line to protect our homes and land. Thank you to Senator Mike McLane for joining me in recognizing their service.

We had a great turnout at the 25th Anniversary celebration of the Madras Airshow! It was a wonderful opportunity to see incredible planes and visit with many in person. I also appreciated the chance to meet with Jefferson County Commissioner Seth Taylor and Madras-Jefferson County Chamber of Commerce Executive Director Debbie Taylor.

I had a couple of good meetings in Wamic today! I was joined by Wasco County Commissioner Jeff Justesen for lunch and toured the Pine Hollow Lakeside Reservoir with proprietor Nick Marquez. It was great to visit with both of them and discuss the work that they are doing in the community.

I had an excellent discussion with the outfitter community in Maupin, including river, fishing, and hunting guides. We discussed issues affecting the lower Deschutes and John Day rivers which includes fish populations and permitting challenges. I appreciate their insight and the thoughtful discussion.

Today, I had an excellent meeting with the doctors and staff at the Deschutes Rim Health Clinic in Maupin. Their work is essential to ensuring families across south Wasco County have access to quality health care. Thank you for your invaluable service to the community! https://t.co/c5qlil75CE

It was great meeting with The Dalles Mayor Rich Mays and his team to discuss my legislation, H.R. 655, The Dalles Watershed Development Act. Protecting the watershed for the City of The Dalles is critical to ensuring reliable access to clean drinking water. My legislation transfers land to The Dalles so the city can pursue an expansion of its drinking water system. This bill has been introduced, received a hearing in the House Natural Resources Committee, and passed out of that Committee unanimously. I look forward to seeing it come before the full House soon!

I had a great discussion with The Dalles Rotary about key provisions in the One Big Beautiful Bill and how it will benefit Oregon’s taxpayers. I always appreciate meeting with Rotarians and hearing about all the good work they do. Thank you for having me and keep it up! https://t.co/6G7e8eIZCA
https://t.co/tptfZo7Sld

I issued a statement regarding recent comments made by Governor Tina Kotek about the impact of the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) on SNAP and Medicaid. You can read my full statement below: https://t.co/oNPEDleeGd

My office is here to help! Recently, we helped Andrew, an Air Force retiree, after he and his family were unexpectedly dropped from their Tricare coverage. My office successfully worked to have him and his family coverage reinstated with no lapse, making sure that they receive the care that they deserve! 

If you need assistance with a federal agency, call us at (541) 776-4646 or visit my website here ➡️ https://t.co/QEmHwnafGm

Always great to join RL Garrigus on KSJJ 102.9! We covered everything from wildfire preparedness to the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB), and working with the Administration to deliver for rural Oregon. https://t.co/SWD3xLjrxF

Great to join KTVZ in Bend to discuss the need for forest management, key components of the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB), and our work on the Energy and Commerce Committee to lower gas prices. https://t.co/reTTECVg7Z

Thank you to all who joined and heard me speak at this year’s Eastern Oregon Economic Summit. It was a pleasure to open the Natural Resources section of the program and discuss how my work and focus in Congress are on continuing to help grow Eastern Oregon’s and our state’s economy through economic partnerships, cooperative resource management strategies, and sustainable growth opportunities across the region.

I joined KOBI-TV, News at Sunrise, to discuss President Trump’s recent FEMA declaration for Douglas, Curry, and Coos Counties, which will help them recoup funds from the extreme flooding from this spring.  

I am continuing to work closely with local leaders and federal agencies to ensure resources are delivered timely and effectively to those in need.

Good news! Yesterday, President Trump approved a Major Disaster Declaration for the State of Oregon (specifically, Douglas, Curry, and Coos Counties), triggering the release of federal funds to help communities recover from severe storms, flooding, landslides, and mudslides. I want to thank President Trump, his staff, and FEMA for their essential support and swift action.

I am pleased to announce that the White House has authorized FEMA to provide funding to help fight the Highland Fire currently burning in Crook County, Oregon. We must protect the homes, infrastructure, and natural resources threatened by this dangerous wildfire. This authorization will help the Crook County Community. I will continue to work with FEMA and other agencies as they respond to wildfires.
Happy Independence Day! 🇺🇸 https://t.co/wY5KqM7eiV

Yesterday, I voted YES on the Big Beautiful Bill. I voted YES because I believe that the laws and policies contained in this bill, among many things in the bill, will protect America’s credit, drive the economy to new heights, and begin the long and difficult road toward reducing dependence on government. This bill would never have passed but for Speaker Johnson and President Trump’s outstanding efforts to bring our Republican caucus together. They deserve serious credit for their irreplaceable and essential efforts.

Today, I joined my colleagues on the @NatResources Federal Lands Subcommittee for an oversight hearing titled “Fix Our Forests Act: Advancing Innovative Technologies to Improve Forest Management and Prevent Wildfires.” During the hearing, I focused on the current state of wildland firefighter staffing and their readiness for the upcoming fire season. I also focused in on how we can use new technology to identify areas in which growth is exceeding what is being extracted from our forests. Utilizing these tools is essential to maintaining healthier forests and reducing the risk of catastrophic wildfires.

Since PILT payments began in 1977, the U.S. Government, through the Department of Interior, has distributed more than $12.6 billion dollars. PILT makes sense, since the Government collects more than $20.7 billion in revenue ANNUALLY from commercial activities on public lands. Millions of acres of federal land are located in Oregon counties, but this land cannot be taxed. Nonetheless, these counties and the people in them shoulder the multitude of costs that benefit this land such as maintaining roads, schools, first responders, law enforcement, and fire protection. This PILT program helps defray some of the cost associated with maintaining these crucial services.

https://t.co/BXrIpDdmLY

Read My Press Release Regarding Public Lands, below ⬇️

https://t.co/jWEsqEouiA

On June 22nd, using B2 bombers, 30 tomahawk missiles, and six 30,000 pound “Bunker Busting” bombs, the United States attacked three nuclear sites in Iran. The reason for the attack was to prevent Iran, a country hostile to the United States, Israel, and peace in the Middle East, from using the enriched uranium it had produced at those sites to construct an atomic bomb.

Today, I met with Douglas County Commissioner Tim Freeman, Matt Hill of Douglas Timber Operators, and Pat Skril, District Director of the Douglas Forest Protective Association (DFPA). We discussed my work, as a Member of the House Natural Resources Committee, to improve forest management. I was encouraged to learn about the Douglas Forest Protective Association’s (DFPA) aggressive initial attack approaches in fighting wildland fires.  

I also saw firsthand the damage left by the MilePost 97 fire (2019) and had the opportunity to tour the DR Johnson Lumber Mill.

It’s been a productive day!

I continue my work on ensuring Kingsley Field in Klamath Falls has a successful transition from the F-15E to the F-35 fighters. Yesterday, I met with Colonel Gaudinksi and Colonel Lambert to get firsthand updates.

The capabilities of Kingsley Field are vitally important to the success of our national defense, and I am prepared to continue to offer strong support for their future missions!

Thank you to the Oregon Institute of Technology for the honor to speak and deliver today’s commencement address to the Class of 2025 in Klamath Falls. Thank you for the invitation from President Nagi Naganathan. It was an honor to celebrate the achievements and hard work of Oregon Tech’s graduates.

Happy 250th birthday to the U.S. Army! 

Thank you to the brave men and women who valiantly serve and have served. Our nation would not be what it is without you. 🇺🇸 https://t.co/jAd0HalGFf

The President’s order is totally consistent with our nation’s fight to win the race for artificial intelligence, superiority, and energy dominance. The people of nation and especially the rate payers of the Northwest are incredibly grateful for this action.
https://t.co/txBKCwGA9Y

I have worked for more than 30 years to protect the irreplaceable Columbia River hydropower electrical system. The Biden Administration did its best to initiate the destruction of that system through improper manipulation of environmental laws and policies. This manipulation was reflected in a memorandum of understanding. Thankfully, President Trump has revoked the Biden Administration’s “Restoring Healthy and Abundant Salmon, Steelhead, and Other Native Fish Populations in the Columbia River Basin” Memorandum. This was exactly the right thing to do and provides a foundation for protection of the Four Lower Snake River dams.

Today, in the @NatResources Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations, on which I serve, hearing titled “Examining the President’s FY26 Budget Request for the Department of the Interior,” I spoke to Secretary Burgum and thanked him for issuing the kill order for the wolf in Lake County and for the agencies response to the ongoing regulatory burdens for irrigators in the Klamath Basin. 

Thank you @SecretaryBurgum for your commitment to effectively utilizing, protecting, and preserving the resources on our federal lands.

Today in the @HouseCommerce Health Subcommittee hearing, “Made in America: Strengthening Domestic Manufacturing and Our Health Care Supply Chain”, on which I serve, I raised concerns about our growing reliance on China for critical materials and the broader impact this has on our healthcare system. 

We must strike a balance between building a stronger domestic supply chain as it is essential to keeping healthcare safe and affordable for all Americans.

Congratulations to Talula Heckendorf, a student from Phoenix High School in Oregon’s Second Congressional District, for winning this year’s Congressional Art Competition with her outstanding piece, “Man Walking Through an Alaskan Town.”

Her artwork will be proudly displayed in the U.S. Capitol for the next year, alongside the winning entries from across the country. It was a pleasure to meet Talula here in Washington, D.C.!

Today during the @NatResources Subcommittee on Federal Lands, I had the opportunity to speak about my bill, H.R. 1655, the Wildfire Communications Resiliency Act. 

My bill provides a targeted exemption from environmental reviews for communications infrastructures located within the footprint of a declared wildfire disaster. This bill represents a commonsense approach to rebuilding critical communications infrastructure and resources in our communities that face growing threats from increasingly severe wildfires. 

I look forward to my bill advancing and continuing to find practical solutions that address wildfire recovery and preparedness.

The Energy and Commerce Committee, on which I serve, is holding a hearing for the FY26 Department of Energy Budget. 

Tune in now ⬇️

Thank you to the American Agri-Women, and Marie Bowers for representing Oregon, and for the opportunity to speak with you today! I appreciated the chance to discuss the importance of public investments in our waterway infrastructure, the challenges we face, and the policy solutions I’m working on in Congress to advance legislation that preserves and improves these critical systems for generations to come.

ICYMI: I joined Kyle on KQEN, Roseburg today to talk about the Big, Beautiful Bill, reducing federal spending, the importance of wildfire prevention as fire season approaches and more. We discussed a number of important issues that impact the 2nd District of Oregon.

Listen to the full interview below ⬇️
https://t.co/58vUjJWPA5

Thank you to Trevor Meyer, President of the Umatilla County Cattlemen’s Association, for meeting me in Washington, D.C.! We had a conversation about the urgent need to address the spread of the New World screwworm which is currently making its was toward the U.S. from South America. We also discussed the ongoing impact of gray wolves in rural communities in Oregon and the impacts on livestock, families, and their pets. Thanks again Trevor for your work in advocating for education for the next generation in the cattle industry!

81 years ago today, brave Allied Expeditionary Forces began the liberation of occupied France, and the world. These brave men put their lives on the line to advance the cause of global freedom. 

We are forever in their debt. https://t.co/W1AjdI4Q8q

Earlier this week, I sat down with Brinkley Hill at the KDRV studios to discuss the recent passage of the Reconciliation Bill, shared an update on Congressional priorities, the vital importance of Medicaid, and spoke about the future of forest management here in Oregon.

In case you missed it, you can watch the full interview here:

Last week, I sent a letter to Administrator Maykovich expressing my support for a federal emergency declaration for Coos, Curry, Douglas, and Harney Counties.  People and property in these counties have been significantly damaged by flooding, landslides, mudslides, and other weather related disasters. Immediate federal assistance is essential to begin the recovery process.

Today, I met with Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and U.S. Forest Service (USFS) officials at the Medford Interagency Office to discuss wildfire preparedness, forest management, and the steps we’re taking to protect Southern Oregon this fire season.

I thank those that attended for meeting with me. I appreciate what they do and the thoughts that they shared.

On this 2025 Memorial Day, I had the great honor to speak at the Eagle Point National Cemetery as we remembered and honored those who made the ultimate sacrifice for our country. 

Thank you to every one at Eagle Point National Cemetery for inviting me to be part of their celebration on this most important day.

This Memorial Day, we pause to honor the brave men and women who answered our nation’s call and made the ultimate sacrifice. Their courage, service and unwavering dedication to our freedoms must never be forgotten. 🇺🇸 https://t.co/m5rnm7sxbi

Thank you to everyone who joined my Telephone Town Hall yesterday! We had over 12,788 constituents join our call and I received well over 470 questions. It was a great to take your questions and hear directly from you about the issues that matter most to Oregon.

This morning, President Trump joined our Republican Conference (all 220 of us) at our weekly meeting in the Capitol. He spoke about the “Big, Beautiful Bill” and took a number of questions. This legislation is a huge step in the direction the American people voted for last November!

Today, I spoke at the @NatResources Subcommittee hearing on Federal Lands, on which I serve, to discuss the important role that Oregon’s Indian tribes could play in improving Oregon’s timber land management. This discussion is a first step towards creating a system where our tribal nations can use their expertise in forest management to help restore our forests to a healthier state and reduce wildfire risk.

40% of my constituency depend on Medicaid. I know how essential and necessary Medicaid is. However, if we are to protect Medicaid so that it can continue to help people who are most vulnerable, we must prevent ineligible and illegal persons from wrongful participation.

Medicaid deserves protection, not exploitation.

The American taxpayers are clear: They want a work requirements. 

This includes:
-80% of Republicans
-60% of Independents 
-47% of Democrats

As we work through this markup, my Democrat colleagues have engaged in speculation and out-right misrepresentation of the context and content of the bill. 

Let me be clear: Medicare and Medicaid are essential programs and they will be protected!

The @HouseCommerce, on which I serve, will be holding a full committee markup on our portion of the budget reconciliation legislation.

Tune in here at 2PM ET ⬇️

I am pleased to join my colleagues in the @westerncaucus in urging Secretary Rollins to expand the use of targeted grazing. Obviously, grazing will reducing vegetation on our forest floors and on our ranch land, dramatically lowering wildfire risk, while helping restore the health of our federal forests and rangelands.

Don’t Forget! Starting this week, a REAL ID is required to board a domestic flight.

Thank you to the students of Harvest Christian Academy of Baker City, Oregon for meeting with me here in Washington, D.C.! It was a pleasure to talk with you and to discuss your plans and ideas. Thank you so much to take time to visit with us! https://t.co/rveuuhPxCi

As a member of the @NatResources, I am proud to have helped advance legislation that contributes $18.5 billion in savings towards the budget reconciliation package. This is a critical step in ensuring that our nation’s natural resources are managed responsibly and that taxpayer dollars are put to work efficiently.

This morning, I had the honor of welcoming Korean and Vietnam War Veterans to D.C., courtesy of the Honor Flight of Southern Oregon. 

I presented every visiting Veteran with a flag flown over our nation’s Capitol, accompanied by a certificate so indicating, and with a copy of the Congressional Record thanking and recognizing them for their service to our country. 

These patriots defended our country and protected our freedom with honor and courage. They certainly deserve our support and gratitude for their service to our nation.

Last week, I joined several of my colleagues in sending a letter to EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin urging the agency to review and change the Biden Administration’s reckless tailpipe emissions standards. 

We must remove unnecessary bureaucratic roadblocks, protect our economy and consumer choice.

Today, the world mourns the passing of Pope Francis, the 88-year-old pontiff, whose death on Easter Monday reminds us of his enduring legacy of faith, compassion, and unwavering service to humanity. https://t.co/03irkTSblB

Thank you to Deputy Assistant Secretary for the Air Force Robert Moriarty, Lieutenant Colonel Benson with the Department of the Air Force, and Colonel Hammons with the National Guard Bureau for meeting with me last week, here in Washington, D.C., to discuss the future of Kingsley Field and its upcoming F-35 missions.

I have a great update to share! After months of work, my office has helped Taylor’s Sausage in Cave Junction recover $688,181.00 through the IRS Employee Retention Credit.

If you need assistance with a federal issue, my office is here to help. Please don’t hesitate to reach out at https://t.co/YzXdDtamJE or call our District Office at (541) 776-4646

If you or someone you know is facing a similar issue with a federal agency, please do not hesitate to contact my office at (541) 776-4646 or visit my website at https://t.co/QEmHwnafGm. My team and I are here to help!

This morning, I joined KTVZ to discuss the serious challenges facing Oregon and our nation. In Congress, I will continue to push for fiscal responsibility, the preservation of essential programs such as Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid, and the protection of Oregon’s natural resources, especially as wildfires continue to threaten our forests.
https://t.co/H01r9kl4A7

Today’s meeting of the @HouseCommerce, Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing, and Trade, on which I sit, focused upon the “Take It Down” Act. This act if enacted, would protect children from “revenge pornography” by criminalizing publication of harmful images and requiring websites to quickly remove them.

We must act to protect our children from these and other horrific uses of social media.

Instead of sitting on our hands and allowing the issues associated with an exploding wolf population go unaddressed. Congress must delist the gray wolf. 

The gray wolf must be delisted because it is no longer endangered. Our communities deserve to be safe from depredation. https://t.co/h6yI8LV7cQ

The Emergency Commodity Assistance Program (ECAP) opens TOMORROW, March 19, 2025! 

The Farm Service Agency (FSA) will begin mailing letters to known eligible producers tomorrow. This is the first step in delivering agricultural aid promised in the December disaster relief bill. For more details, please contact your local FSA office ⬇️

H.R. 7938 is a huge win for the farmers and ranchers who have supported Klamath communities for the over a century! Proud to see it become law.

I am proud to share that my bill, H.R. 7938, which passed the House and Senate floor last year, has officially been signed into law by the President!

This is a big win! This law protects the Klamath Project’s patrons from being held responsible for any costs attributable to Keno and Link River dams. I would like to thank everyone who played a role in making it happen—those who helped draft the bill, provided critical background, and testified in support. Thank you to the Water, Wildlife and Fisheries Subcommittee for their hard work in scheduling the bill and ensuring it reached the floor.

Serving my third term as Oregon’s Second Congressional Districts’ Congressman is both an honor and a privilege. 

I look forward, in this 119th Congress to work alongside with my Republican colleagues in the House and in the Senate to deliver real solutions that put Americans and our country first.

Today marks the start of the 119th Congress! It is time to get back to work for the American people. Together with President Donald Trump, Senate Republicans and House Republicans, we are ready to tackle the challenges ahead and fight to put our nation back on the track!

I am happy to announce my bill the Klamath Basin Agreement Support Act, which previously passed the House, just PASSED the Senate!

This is legislation that will help our farmers and ranchers from the adverse effects of removing the four non-federal dams on the Klamath River.

I am happy to see my bill, the Klamath Basin Agreement Support Act, H.R. 7938 pass by voice on the House floor today! 

For generations, farmers and ranchers have shouldered the burdens of unpredictable weather, skyrocketing production costs, and wildly fluctuating markets— all while using less water and feeding our nation.

This legislation will hold the federal government to honoring critical commitments promised to communities of the Klamath Basin.

“This bill is the result of hundreds of hours of negotiation and collaboration by those who live, work, and recreate in Malheur County, The Burns Paiute Tribe, and many environmental organizations.  It is based on a bill introduced last year by Senator Ron Wyden.  It is a provisional bill, but it contains those elements needed to protect the land, plants, animals and communities that rely upon that land.  I want to thank the Senator for his personal involvement and for his staff’s work, and I look forward to successfully passing this bill out of the House within the next few weeks,” said Congressman Cliff Bentz.

“Congressman Bentz and I have been working together to pass Owyhee legislation before the end of the year. His announcement today of the upcoming hearing in the House Natural Resources Subcommittee on Public Lands on his "Oregon Owyhee Wilderness and Community Protection Act" takes a significant step forward toward achieving that goal,” Senator Ron Wyden said. “I applaud Congressman Bentz’s thoughtful and constructive approach and am looking forward, as we continue to work together on this bill, to success on legislation that leaves the farmers, ranchers, preservationists, Tribes and all the residents of Eastern Oregon the true winners of the economic and preservation gains this legislative approach can achieve.”

As Chair of the Subcommittee on Water, Wildlife, and Fisheries, I was pleased to hear how locally driven, collaborative efforts in Central Oregon are making a difference. 

Two clear messages stood out from the witness testimony:
1. We need stronger protection for our watersheds from fire.
2. We must protect our farmers and ranchers from the negative impacts of Endangered Species Act (ESA) implementation.

These witness testimony were insightful, and I’ll be returning to Washington better equipped to draft legislation that addresses these critical issues.

Today, the @NatResources Subcommittee on Water, Wildlife, and Fisheries is in Central Oregon to discuss water issues and explore locally driven solutions!

If you can’t join us in person, tune in here:
